ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Essay writing became more than an academic pursuit for me.i learned how to use it as a form of personal and political expression.
I improved my writing lots and learnt lots of techniques for my own writing, as well as ways to critically look at the writing of myself and others.
Close reading, reading for craft, creative and personal writing

In this class, I learned much more about strategies of structure and effective articulation in writing. Through the close readings and writing exercises, I have learned more about what makes a good writer, how to create a message with impact, how to use a tone that is convincing, and how to articulate my ideas into tangible English words.
How to read essays to find techniques that can be used for own writing, how to write coherent non-academic essays using more fluid structures

Writing personal narratives, cultural criticisms, argumentative essays, detailing space/place/time, including humor/satire into a piece, and writing about people by interviewing them plus other sources! I gained insights related to writing with my reader(s) in mind, writing from a place/position/identity near me. Skills-wise, I became more comfortable reading and writing modern essays aside from the typical research/academic-oriented papers that are very common in the Yale classroom.

This class truly changed the way I see writing and reading and helped me develop a newfound appreciation for both. I really loved the way the class was structured into five "themes," and that we got to read samples of writing from each theme before trying it ourselves. Rather than read to merely absorb information, this class encourages you to read and pay attention to the effect that the author's words have on you, as well as the strategies they employ to achieve that effect. In terms of skills gained, I learned how to analyze a text for main ideas and purpose, weigh the pros and cons of employing certain literary strategies and formats, and structure my own writing in a way that best conveys my purpose.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think professor Barnes Ross was particularly strong at choosing writers that were not only interesting to study for their craft but also thematically very interesting. I feel I not only understand how to use essays, but also some of the history of how essays have been used.
Unclear grading outcomes.

The workshopping essays was great. Loved hearing what others were writing and getting their own feedback on my writing. One thing I might change would be the order of the essays - the first paper (self-portrait) was the hardest to write because I didnt really feel ready to write about that yet, whereas starting with the portrait of someone else/place essay mightve been easier
Strengths: workshop format, balance of reading and writing; weaknesses: stressful grading

Strengths: this course really pushes you to be critical during every discussion and every time you write! It is challenging, but you really grow as a writer within the course of one semester. The workshop process (discussing another students work) is especially a strength because you get to critique another persons work and reflect back on yours
Weaknesses: I sometimes wished there was more time in-class to write and workshop. Class time was heavily focused on discussing readings, which was useful, but we didnt get much time to practice writing ourselves in class

Strengths: I loved the variety of essays we were able to read, and the feedback we received on essays was in-depth, clear and always quite helpful.
Weaknesses: none

Strengths: a wide variety of readings to discuss and learn from each session; the pacing of essays allows for ample time to write, get feedback, and revise; in general, class materials were pretty accessible.

Weaknesses: I can't think of many.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Engl 120 teaches a fantastic mode of expression
Yes, really interesting concept for a course. I think it depends on the prof you get.

Yes, some of the discussions were fun and I think I improved my writing. It did slightly feel like more serious essay topics were more likely to give you a better grade than the more trivial essay topics but I enjoyed the course overall.
Yes, I'd recommend this course to any student willing to work fairly hard to improve their writing and develop an appreciation for modern essays

I would recommend this course to any student! It is just a great class to sharpen your writing practices, as well as be exposed to different types of writing styles from classmates and other assigned readings. It is also a great way to receive clear feedback from peers and your professor, so you can understand how your writing can become more effective.

Absolutely! It was a very challenging class, but a very rewarding one as well. You get so much feedback from your professor & peers throughout the semester, and you can always approach your professor for further questions on ways to improve your draft. The selected readings are also very thought-provoking about the world (not merely exemplary in technique).

I would recommend this course! It's a good introduction for those not super familiar with creative writing, and the personal nature of the essays we wrote also allowed me to do a lot of personal reflection that I found fulfilling.

Highly recommend! ENGL120 is an amazing WR credit and you'll see how many new writing techniques and insights you gain, especially with Professor Baynes-Ross as your instructor you'll receive clear and timely feedback on all your submissions. Of course, the quality of the work you produce is contingent upon the time you put into class but overall you'll become so much more equipped to write at and outside of Yale. This course is probably one of the most enlightening that I've taken.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student! The experiences we read about represented a wide array of authors with various backgrounds-- some very well-known, and some lesser known, including some former Yale students. The writing we read in this class effectively helped me, and I'm sure other students, view the world from other people's eyes, as we touched on important topics such as racism, cultural assimilation, and mourning loss. All pieces provided such a unique perspective on a wide variety of other topics too, such as school, video games, and food, and I have a much deeper appreciation for all of these things now having taken this class.
